elements.label: sec_1
elements.text: Approximation and Limits Modules: A4, B1

elements.label: sec_2
elements.text: 1. Consider the following Fermi estimation problem.

elements.label: para
elements.text:
“If in 2014, you had downloaded all the data on the entire internet, burned the data onto
CDs, and stacked the CDs on top of each other, how tall would the stack be?”

elements.label: para
elements.text:
Find upper and lower bounds for what the height of the stack might be. State any assumptions about
data you use in your calculations.

elements.label: para
elements.text: First, I need to find upper and lower bounds for the amount of data on the internet in 2014.

elements.label: para
elements.text:
Live Science that the amount of data on the internet in 2014 was 1 million exabytes [1] . ACI said
that in 2013, the amount of data on the internet increased by 5 exabytes per day [2] . This would
mean that the amount of data by the start of 2014 was 5 * 365 = 1825 exabytes of data. Hence, a
lower and upper bound can be created:

elements.label: equ
elements.text: $$1825\cdot10^{18}bytes\leq Amount\ of\ data\ in\ 2014\leq1,000,000\cdot10^{18}bytes$$

elements.label: para
elements.text:
The amount of CDs that it would take to store a certain amount of data is equal to the amount of
data divided by the amount of data an average CD can hold. According to Andrea Stein of
ItStillWorks.com, the average CD can hold 700 megabytes, or 700 * 106 bytes, of data[3]. Dividing
the expression by this value yields:

elements.label: equ
elements.text: $$\frac{1825}{700} \cdot 10^{12} CDs \leq  Amount of CDs needed  \leq \frac{1,000,000}{700} \cdot 10^{12} CDs$$

elements.label: para
elements.text:
The total height of a stack of CDs would be the amount of CDs multiplied by the average height of 1
CD. According to Britannica.com, the average height of 1 CD is 1.2 mm, or 0.0012 metres [4].
Multiplying the expression by this value gives us our answer

elements.label: equ
elements.text: $$\frac{1825}{700} \cdot 0.0012 \cdot 10^{12} m \leq  Height of the stack  \leq \frac{1,000,000}{700} \cdot 0.0012 \cdot 10^{12} m$$

elements.label: para
elements.text: Rounding off gives

elements.label: equ
elements.text: $$3,128,571,429 m \leq  Height of the stack  \leq 1,714,285,714,000 m$$

elements.label: para
elements.text: Quite the range!

elements.label: para
elements.text:
2. Find the following limit, fully justifying your reasoning using mathematical principles we have covered.
Remember to use complete sentences as part of your response.

elements.label: para
elements.text: Since there is a sine in the function, I will start off by trying squeeze theorem

elements.label: para
elements.text: The bounds for sine are

elements.label: equ
elements.text: $$-1 \leq \sin \left(\frac{1}{x-2}\right) \leq 1$$

elements.label: para
elements.text: Adding $x^{2}$ to both sides:

elements.label: equ
elements.text: $$x^{2}-1 \leq x^{2}+\sin \left(\frac{1}{x-2}\right) \leq x^{2}+1$$

elements.label: para
elements.text:
To get the original function in the middle, we would have to raise each part of the inequality to the power of
negative 1. However, to do so, we would also have to flip the direction of the inequalities because if $a\geq b$, then

elements.label: equ
elements.text: $$\frac{1}{a} \leq \frac{1}{b}  since a larger denominator means a smaller fraction. Hence, $$

elements.label: equ
elements.text: $$\frac{1}{x^{2}-1} \geq \frac{1}{x^{2}+\sin \left(\frac{1}{x-2}\right)} \geq \frac{1}{x^{2}+1}$$

elements.label: para
elements.text: To get the function we are trying to find the limit of in the centre, we just multiply by x - 2:

elements.label: equ
elements.text: $$\frac{x-2}{x^{2}-1} \geq \frac{x-2}{x^{2}+\sin \left(\frac{1}{x-2}\right)} \geq \frac{x-2}{x^{2}+1}$$

elements.label: para
elements.text: Let $g(x)$ be equal to the function on the left and $h(x)$ be equal to the function on the right

elements.label: equ
elements.text: $$\begin{array} { r } { \operatorname* { l i m } _ { x \to 2 } g ( x ) } \\ { = \operatorname* { l i m } _ { x \to 2 } \frac { x - 2 } { x ^ { 2 } - 1 } } \end{array}$$

elements.label: para
elements.text: And

elements.label: equ
elements.text: $$\lim _{x \to 2} h(x)$$

elements.label: para
elements.text: Therefore, since

elements.label: equ
elements.text: $$h ( x ) \leq \frac { x - 2 } { x ^ { 2 } + \sin ( \frac { 1 } { x - 2 } ) } \leq g ( x )$$

elements.label: para
elements.text: And

elements.label: equ
elements.text: $$\lim_{x\to2}h(x)=\lim_{x\to2}g(x)=0$$

elements.label: para
elements.text: We can conclude that

elements.label: equ
elements.text: $$\lim _{x \to 2} \frac{x-2}{x^{2}+\sin \left(\frac{1}{x-2}\right)}=0$$

elements.label: para
elements.text: 3. In three sentences or less, reflect on the similarities and differences in the the math used to solve these problem

elements.label: para
elements.text:
Both questions were similar in that they both required the manipulation of a double inequality. However, question
1 required me to do my own research to create bounds and then use more research to find a range for a value,
meaning the nature of the question required inequalities. On the other hand, question 2 required me to find the
value of a limit, where the double inequality came into play as a result of a mathematical theorem that I chose to
approach the problem with, meaning the nature of the question was not about inequalities but rather inequalities
were simply a tool used in the method that I chose for the question and the question does not necessarily need
inequalities to be solved.
